div.p: Greetings. Regarding excommunication, about which you wrote to me, I write nothing; this matter cannot be explained in a few words. As long as I live and God does not take away His grace from me, I will look to those things which are of peace and edification in the church, so that nothing is established by me from which infinite evils arise, and thus a much more abundant harvest of dissensions and tyranny of hypocritical men than of union and integrity. I recently sent you a copy of my Summary or Compendium written on true religion. This book has been translated, albeit somewhat, into the Latin language. Now I submit to your piety an Apologetic exposition, which I opposed to the books of Westphal, Timann, and other Saxons. I beg your kindness, that if anything in these my writings displeases you, you may freely indicate it. I cannot say more at present. Let us pray to the Lord diligently, that He may unite distracted minds and preserve all things tending towards utter ruin by His power.

I seem to see a great judgment of God impending over us. Men do not want to be healed by remedies; I fear that iron and fire must be applied by the Lord. Let us watch and pray. Farewell with all yours, whom you will greet diligently.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Ambrosius Blarer, faithful minister of the church in Biel/Bienne, esteemed lord and dearest brother. Biel.
